text: hello everyone and welcome to today's webinar what devops and sres need to know about mobile observability my name
is Colin contrary I am the head of content here at Embrace and I will be your MC for today's webinar for the best
audio experience please use your computer's audio as opposed to dialing in and now before we get started with
the webinar we'd like to cover a few housekeeping items so the first thing is this webinar
is being recorded and it will be made available to you after it's processed later today so you can rewatch it and
share with your team the second is we will have a section at the end uh for
questions so please use the go to webinar chat box to ask any questions and we will get to as many of them as we
have time for at the end of the webinar and with all that said I'd like to hand it over to today's speaker Frederick
hello Frederick hey Colin thanks for that intro uh hi everybody I'm Frederick
Newberg I'm the CTO at Embrace I've been working in the mobile ecosystem for 15
years and uh also have a fair amount of experience working on backend systems
and monitoring them so looking forward to sharing some learnings about mobile observability and how it's different
than a lot of things that you have to do for uh backend observability um just a few quick words
about Embrace for those of you who are not familiar with us um we are the only
uh user focused mobile observability uh provider in the market
with an open Telemetry solution we uh have open- source sdks that you are free
to embed in your apps and uh you can gather observability data with those uh
and they will be delivered using uh open Telemetry standards and you can choose
to send them to your own observability backends or you can send them to our backend where
we do a lot of analysis and work around a lot of the observability issues that
we're going to be discussing that exist in Mobile today so without further Ado let's dive into things so why why are we
all here uh well uh we are here to talk about how the fundamentals in Mobile are
different and how they impact observability so uh I'm going to step on
a limb here and assume that most of you know a fair bit about backend observability so I'm going to contrast
how that is different than mobile observability so often in back end
you're monitoring things like Services where you have small well- defined amounts of work that you know you're
looking to complete in milliseconds if you have end points that take seconds or
even uh tens of seconds that would be not the best performance experience that
you're looking for on back end whereas like in mobile you monitor highly variable Behavior over the course of
tens of seconds or minutes or even hours and with backend you typically
have server types that are pretty consistent controlled uh you can upgrade them a lot
of you are probably on cloud Solutions where click of a button or deploying some scripts or running some uh run
books will make those changes happen and you can go from one set of server types to another and it'll be easy and it'll
be well defined uh in Mobile that's not the case you may have an app that you're
responsible for that has over 4,000 different device models with at least 10
users each that we're seeing in a day um in a lot of Android apps we see that the most dominant device May account for
like a couple of percent only of the total user base in back end the networking is
controlled by you and is hopefully most of the time uh stable and predictable uh
whereas in Mobile it's certainly not you control very little of the network other
than you know where you do your data ingestion but uh data is coming from all
corners of the internet and sometimes people will have highly variable experiences even during the course of a
session they may walk down into the basement or get in an elevator and what was a great connection turns into a
terrible one or no connection at all in backend you typically deploy versions
rather deterministically maybe you have Canary bills that you put out there that run a small percentage of the workload
and when that all looks good you upgrade but rarely do you run a large variety of app versions um that's not the case in
Mobile not you have really no control in many cases of when customers upgrade uh
some install one and keep that uh so being used to supporting multiple app
version needs to become the new Norm so hopefully that has sort of set
the context on how really everything is in many ways like the opposite in Mobile
land than it is in backend land and we're going to dive a little bit deeper into Mobile to kind of give you some
more concrete examples of how things are different so uh we're going to start out
by talking about how to think about mobile interactions and um really thinking in
terms of sessions so we we look at a session as an abstraction for capturing a segment of app Behavior you kind of
need to come up with some abstraction for that and um the goal here of the
session abstraction is to basically two things one is to align with how users
think about their app interactions because ultimately when you're trying to debug things that really helps you helps
you understand what was the you did the user experience what were their intents and then also how the operating system
treats app behavior and uh there really two primary modes of operations for
mobile apps and we'll get into a little more detail on that in few slides but there's foreground mode where the app is
being displayed on the screen and maybe being interacted with but also background mode which can be doing some
very important tasks to make the overall and user experience what they expected to be um and really one of the key
things too to think about with mobile is that sessions maintain State uh if
you're used to monitoring backend Services you're probably used to a much
more stateless experience uh between requests
whereas in Mobile I state is maintained over a very long period of time
sometimes longer than you wish it was because it cause complications for you we'll get into a little bit uh more what
that means when we talk about the foreground and background modes so the other thing just to kind of
like uh give a sense of how long sessions can be like if you compare this
to what I mentioned earlier where you want Network requests to take on the
order of milliseconds um session durations in Mobile are much much longer if you look
at the vertical scale it's in seconds not milliseconds U and these are a
couple of different media apps uh but you can see pretty different behavior from the end users where you know the
p50 of app number one is still quite low and uh you know significantly less than
a minute whereas like the p50 for app 2 is probably around a minute and when you look at like the P95 times um they've
diverged quite a bit where you know the P95 is at and probably about three three
and a half minutes for the blue one and um much much longer uh at 10,000 seconds
or I'm sorry a thousand seconds uh for app number two so uh even there it's like this is to kind of illustrate that
there is not a one size fit all usage patterns are going to be different you're going to find some apps have
extremely long times like maybe you have a podcasting app and people actually put it in the foreground and it'll sit there
literally for hours and maybe there are other things like a weather app where people like breeze in see like yeah
great it's going to be sunny and then they leave 10 seconds later one of the things too uh building
on the statefulness that I mentioned earlier to think about is what we've
called session stitching um users often use apps in bursts where they're looking
to carry out they have some goal maybe like let's say they're using a food
ordering app like door Dash um they come in they start looking around for food
they get a phone call they get interrupted they take the phone call they get back in there they pick a
restaurant they order the food they go do something else they look to see where
the delivery is and then when the delivery arrives they go maybe like raided give a tip something like that so
if you think about a sessions being uh when the app is in the foreground or is
in the background you'll see there are a lot of transitions between those and given how application state is managed
oftentimes the process will for the app will be launched and it
will sometimes like stay active in the background sometimes it'll be terminated by the OS because there are other apps
competing for resources you really don't have a whole lot of control over that um but the idea of kind of keeping this
journey of uh interaction uh together is important because you're trying to
understand like oh maybe there was like data that was delivered here through an endpoint that's going to be used in the next SE session so it's really important
to understand the whole path that the user took in terms of debugging uh
issues a lot of the time so as I mentioned there are two primary modes of operation there's the
foreground mode which is pretty straightforward you know the app is as the name would imply in the foreground
and maybe you're just viewing it maybe you're actually interacting with it it doesn't really matter if it's displayed
it's in the foreground um but the background is also
a really important uh component of how an app operates and it'll vary a little
bit depending on the type of app how much is done in the background but um a surprisingly large number of apps have
critical things that do happen in the background and this can be getting push
notifications uh and responding to those it may be that you have a scheduled
download of data that occurs if you are on WiFi and at 3:00 a.m every morning it
downloads some data to make sure it's ready for the next day uh it may be a
case of shortly after you backgrounded the app uh app is working to complete
stuff uh that was started in the foreground maybe you're uploading video
and those things are really challenging to understand because I you know they
they happen outside the scope of when the user was interacting with it but ultimately when the user comes back to
use app if you haven't handled the background Behavior correctly then you may leave the user with an experience
that is not what they expected so understanding what is happening in the background can be really critical for
many applications that's unlike a you know a back backend service where there normally is really only just one mode of
operation all right so next let's turn to understanding the mobile operating environment which has a lot of
differences than what you might be used to from a running a backend service so
the first thing that I kind of alluded to earlier is that there are lots of different devices so here's a fairly
pedestrian app in our system it's five million sessions one million users in a day and if this is an Android app it
would be quite common for it to have like 4,000 different device models um
these May range from quite old Android 6 Android 7 devices um all the way up to
more modern Android 14 devices from a SL of Manufacturers on iOS it will look a little bit different um You probably
might still have about 70 80 90 different models in iOS but obviously
with just one manufacturer um it's not going to be quite as broad but there's still an opportunity for lots of things
to be different lots of things to go wrong even with that number of devices but just thinking about the fact that
you have all these different devices is is pretty important um and that kind of leads me
into like the things that you normally are used to controlling for in back and app really don't exist um you have no
say in how much CPU and RAM you have to support the app it's whatever the device
had and you know things have certainly gotten better with a lot of new devices
having you know four gigs six gigs of RAM um and reasonable
CPUs but they're still a lot of devices out there that are either older um or
sold into certain markets where they're looking for more economical device options um so some of our customers we
found really uh some challenges dealing with the lower tier devices and you kind
of have to think through that because often times in QA you aren't really focusing on that um how much dis space
you have available is not under your control if uh you're running out of dis spas on your backend servers you
provision more dis spas or you get more servers or you use something like a you
know cloud storage where there isn't really a strict bound um that's not the case with
uh mobile where you are stuck with whatever device the person chose and how
much space have left on it surprisingly many devices are pretty low on disk space I
was surprised when we first started to see just how many devices are running
within a gig or two of being full excuse
me um the network bandwidth is not under your control control uh you really don't
have any saying what kind of network the device is on and you really can't say that even
over the course of a session that things will stay consistent um the uh the app
will often restart um between sessions you really don't have any say in how
that happens um and and the OS will determine whether it happens or not this
unlike where when you're running back in Services you kind of get to choose when
you restart your apps most of the
time the um performance across different devices
will vary quite a bit um we um did some tests on iOS and we
benchmarked what the difference was based upon the release year of the
device and it's quite interesting if you look at this um the we benchmarked here
to just like 2023 devices being Benchmark to one and you'll notice that
um even if you just go out to 2019 excuse
me that you will have a 2X difference
in the performance that you uh you will see out of your device so that means
that if you're doing performance monitoring you kind of need to uh adjust
for that and the Baseline you pick should probably be related to a device
or a device year category otherwise you may either fool yourself into thinking
that you have a problem when there really isn't one uh or you
may think that you're seeing improvements when really all you're seeing is people getting newer devices
over time when uh really you didn't make any improvements to your your own
code one thing that may be a little bit surprising is not getting data delivered
in a timely fashion um the uh the norm
in backend is that you will have an agent that is running on your server in
your container uh and it's going to deliver stuff pretty much immediately to
your observative ability uh solution uh that's not really true uh at
least not consistently true with mobile um as you can see here like we're
looking at four different apps where we're looking at how long is the delay
uh between when an event occurred and when it's delivered and you can see in app number
one almost everything gets delivered within a minute of it happening so that's great and um the second app it's
not bad either uh but by the time that you get to third and fourth app you can see that there's actually like a lot of
data being delivered um even a day out or more than
a day out and um you know this happens due to network connectivity things maybe
people started a session offline maybe they started online and completed
offline maybe their internet connection turned poor and things couldn't be delivered um and it's really important
to think about how this affects your overall observability system uh metrics
will change as more data is delivered and processed can your system handle that that's something that we spend
quite a bit of time working on at Embrace to get right and if you're looking to export data to different
systems that don't support updates you know you have to kind of make a decision like well when is enough data present
that you can export and get a good picture uh versus like uh you know did I
wait too long and then you know I wanted to be aware of something that was happening but I was hesitating to export
because I didn't feel like I'd had enough data and the right answer for dealing with this uh oftenest app or or
or specific so there's really no right answer to this it's something where I
would say your mileage may vary and you need to kind of assess where you stand with what the delay profile is for your
app um also I mentioned earlier that you know app version adoption is nothing
guaranteed and here we can see certain apps uh which have different adoption
profiles and you know again the first two they're doing pretty well uh they
have probably about like 85 90% people on the latest version uh but then as you
move further down you see that there are
versions or applications that have four five six versions that have dominant or
not dominant but significant usage on them and you kind of need to think about how you want to deal with that it's
obviously some users aren't getting the latest and greatest feat fees uh so you
may have things where there was a bug fix put on a version that's not being adopted and also a different perspective
to take is like when can you deprecate things on the back end uh how do you manage your app versions if you have uh
if you look at app number five right if you um deleted or wanted to delete an
endpoint that was not used in the last five vers versions it's like well you still have
about you know 10 15% of your traffic on version you know that six versions old
and older uh so are you willing to remove that end point from the backend
service and have the experience break for those customers or are you willing
to keep it around longer even though it may be like you know leading to detect that so those are some of the challenges
that you'll be faced with given that you don't really have full control uh in most cases of app version
adoption all right let's move on to like understanding some of the ecosystem
constraints so one of the first things to be aware of is that you don't have
Rude access on these devices uh privacy has become an Ever bigger thing on iOS
over the years and Android really isn't far behind um you're not going to be running an agent on the device and you
have to acquire all the data you get from the context of the app uh both Android and iOS provide some apis that
kind of help you work around this to some extent but it's fairly minimal and um the real takeaway I think
is like you have no visibility into what is going on around you uh you might be
able to get some pretty decent stats for your app um but you don't know if some
other app is doing a download in the background that's impacting Network manwith or or if some other app is using
some amount of CPU or maybe there are multiple apps that are using CPU and is kind of hurting you a little bit you
just don't know whether that's happening and uh that's sort of by Design I mean as I mentioned privacy is a huge thing
in Mobile and you know you don't want to give that visibility which could be used
for nefarious reasons and that is definitely a challenge in
observability there are also a lot of performance rules that you need to think about um when you're running backend Services
it's kind of like up to you to set what the rules are maybe you want to stop certain runaway processes or runaway uh
requests but here you have to kind of live with what the ecosystem enforces
and iOS will kill your app for a large number of performance reasons if you use
too much CPU for example you have 30 seconds after going to the background to
take care of everything you want to take care of before iOS will just terminate
your process um if you have long hangs if you use excessive IO where you're
writing a lot you know to uh persist in memory there are limits on that and um
some of these things might be really hard even to see in uh QA or during
development uh but if you have a million devices producing millions of sessions a
day you will see these types of Errors occurring Android is a little less aggressive um but Google has other ways
of punishing you in terms of discoverability for poor performing apps uh if you have a crash rate that exceeds
uh their prescribed Norm it'll be harder to find your app when searching in the
App Store same for anr application not responsive rate startup time so Google
is a little more transparent in these things um admittedly they don't provide a whole lot of data to uh help you solve
the problems especially the anrs is like a big thing where uh we've done a lot of work around to make those more solvable
than what uh Google data really allows you uh when you or gives you when you
try to tackle them um so there's a bit more transparency but it you know there
there's definitely room for improvement there from the ecosystem maintainers in my opinion and back ground behavior is
strictly regulated uh much more so on IOS and Android there's a whole lot of rules there's a whole lot of modes you
can operate in iOS there things where you can go get uh exemptions from Apple
because you have a certain type of app and if you deal with Bluetooth or uh things like that you may get exemptions
or if you're a music player um Android's a little less strict but you want to avoid running a foul of them because uh
iOS will punish you when you exceed the rules and then it will give your app
less opportunity to do stuff in the background crash reporting is also like something I think is worth calling out
because obviously it's you know looking into crashes being aware of crashes is
of a primary concern for app developers and owners of apps uh probably the most
commonly used metric in the mobile ecosystem is Crash free percentage so
this is something that we really focus on uh some things to be aware of both iOS crashes and Android native crashes
they are going to be reported on next launch you really don't have a whole lot of saying that just how the ecosystem
Works um both of them require symbolication which means that you know
you need to take some of the artifacts created at build time combined with the data coming off the device at run time
and uh combine that to produce human readable um stack traces and that can be
a little bit challenging uh We've certainly found a lot of corner cases over the years that we've had to uh
build in support form Android jbm crashes are typically reported
immediately um most of them will require the obfuscation uh it's pretty much industry
standard I would say to uh obfuscate and Minify apps using tools that come in the
Android tool chain so what you have coming off the device is probably also Al not going to be human readable and um
one other thing that's noteworthy about Android native crashes is that uh most Android Unity crashes are of this type
so even if you have um an Android app and you're think oh it's going to be mostly jbm crashes for certain things
where you have Frameworks uh that are used to build the apps they may uh lead you to having
native crashes which typically are a little bit harder to tackle than the jbm
crashes all right so the last thing we're going to dive into detail is clients side networking I think this is
an interesting thing to think about because you're used to thinking like oh
well I have a lot of visibility into my networking and how that's going because
I monitor on the back end and while there's certainly an element of Truth to that I feel like it doesn't tell the
full story um starting off with the fact that not all requests make it to the
backend for a variety of reasons uh the first one's probably pretty obvious right like hey you have
no internet connection and uh it may seem kind of silly to include that but I do include it because I am continue to
be surprised by how few apps gracefully handle the lack of an internet
connection or the loss of an internet connection um it's getting better but uh
the percentage of apps is surprisingly small in my opinion that handle that
gracefully you have DNS failures if you can't resolve the host name to an IP
address your backend isn't going to see the request and while you may get some data
when the connection is interrupted or the SSL handshake fails things like that um my experience is like that data is
not necessarily easy to correlate to individual users if you're trying to tie
it together with other data it can be kind of hard to see what's going on uh obviously if this handshake fails you're
not going to have a whole lot of information about that request um and then there's the case where maybe your
server load is ey you like you're you were getting hit with a um usage Spike
that the system wasn't quite ready to handle and that may mean that you're not
really logging everything stuff just kind of fall into the floor and so cases so there are a lot of things where if
you're not looking at it from the client side you're really not going to get a complete picture and perhaps equally importantly
um many requests are not for your back end and many of these Services these
service types are critical to the successful operation of your app you have like payment providers ad providers
map Services cdms there's like a long list of things and I feel like this is a little bit
overlooked if we look at the data uh in terms of
connectivity uh successful connections where things are maybe just like getting
like four and 500 responses I see an outsized number of
these third- Party Services with higher rates compared to uh the backends that
are built by the company uh who are operating the app so I think in some
cases people are just oblivious to they set it up maybe something changed with an authentication key uh maybe they in
some cases we've even had customers who are surprised that certain domains are
still being hit because they thought they removed that SDK or turned off the service so this is something where
you're F uh pretty much Flying Blind if you don't do client side monitoring of
networking for mobile apps um also if you just think about how a request is
made from a mobile app um there can be many components of that request where
you don't have visibility into performance like first of all when you make a request in an app it gets queed
and if you look at the commonly used libraries on both IOS and Android you
will find that there are limits on how many concurrent requests are allowed to
be made to a given domain and we'll see on the next slide where that's really important uh so when
you make the request from the perspective of the app you're like hey that's I'm sitting around waiting but it
may not even hit the network layer for a substantial amount of time um you have
DNS lookup uh surprisingly poor in certain parts of the world as we've
discovered working with some more customers um the whole TCP t plus connection establish
M maybe have visibility into it but it's probably not as good as you wish it was
if you're doing it from the server side and the request
sent obviously you can understand that in the backend processing a request yeah
sure uh but even the response being sent is not always clear um the I I didn't
experiment I I thought I understood the stuff pretty well but I wanted to make sure that I I got it right and I I did
an experiment with engine X where I wanted to understand what it reported as
the uh request time for a given request and uh what I found was that if it was a
small request that fit into the memory buffers in the kernel engine X was just going to kick
the request out and say like oh yeah I I knocked this out in like 10 milliseconds and then it was on the Kernel to
actually deliver it so engine X was kind of under counting that so even there you
may be kind of missing out a little bit on what what's going on if you're relying on that and then obviously the
response parsing by the device you have no visibility into if you send a very
large Json payload U by the time something's actually done with that and
information is presented to user that may be a very significant component of the
overall um time spent by a request to go from the point where you initiate it to
where it has delivered value to a customer um as I mentioned earlier
concurrent request concurrency can be a problem uh one of the things that we've seen is that as teams have gone larger
and this has been kind of a shift in the industry I would say over the last six eight years uh where we used to see a
lot of mobile teams where it's was like maybe three four developers on iOS maybe
like three developers on Android now we're seeing a lot of teams that are like 25 50 maybe even a 100 devs and an
outcome of that has been that the structure of the apps have changed the
um the way that you had to break down and modules has changed and that's often meant that people really aren't
communicating as well as they were so you get this where you get a lot of redundant requests that can happen and
here in this case you see that there a whole bunch of requests made to the same end
point excuse me and uh you uh really
didn't need to make all those back-to-back requests but you had people from different teams who weren't talking
to each other and they all needed the same data and here's where you ended up with that like just kind of like dog
piling on on your server uh but also importantly like it hit the que on the
device and maybe you exceeded the map maximum number let's say it was six concurrent requests so maybe you had 10
requests going out and you would have to wait for like one of the first six to
get completed before seven went out and eight went out and I which really slows down the overall operation of the device
if you're looking at the back end you're like hey I'm knocking out these responses in uh respectable amounts of
time but that's really not what the end user is seeing all right so in summary we we
talked about how the fundamentals in Mobile are different there are a lot of things that are the polar opposite in
Mobile observability from what they're in back end observability U we also talked about how you need to think
differently about mobile interactions there's a lot of different things happening in a session uh you may be
dealing with just a somebody who logs in and does a product search and then leaves or you may have somebody who goes
through the entire uh product purchase flow and a session encompasses a lot of different
things uh that's very unlike uh backend Services where very discret things are
done in uh say a single end point also we talked about how the mobile operating
environment is very different than back in environments where you know you don't have a lot of control over things and
there are rules that are imposed on you that you have no say in and that you need to work around and finally we
talked about the client side network monitoring as an example of where you may have some
observability uh with your backend monitoring but you don't have quite as
complete a picture as you really would want to be able
to give uh your mobile developers the best chance to like troubles sheet issues that are reported so thank you
very much I really appreciate you all joining for this webinar and uh log out
today to talk a little bit about this topic of mobile observability thank you
